author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix #34 - don’t coerce to numbers.
body:
Histograms do not require numeric input in general; they merely require ordinal
input and ordinal thresholds for binning. Thus, we were being overly-strict by
coercing everything to numbers.

This also fixes a bug where the Freedman–Diaconis threshold sorted the input
array of values, rather than sorting a copy of the input.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix #24.
body:
If an axis transition interrupts an earlier axis transition, the new transition
will see the exiting ticks for the old transition. If the axis is ordinal, the
position of these ticks may be undefined for both the old and new scale, which
would result in an invalid transform such as `translate(NaN,0)`.

If the new scale’s position for an exiting tick is undefined (as is always the
case with ordinal scales), rather than falling back to the old scale (which may
also be undefined), we simply use the tick’s current transform so that it fades
out in-place.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Rendering improvements!
body:
Offset the axis by a half-pixel so that single-pixel lines exactly cover whole
pixels when the tick position is an integer. This obviates the need for the
crispEdges shape-rendering style when used in conjunction with scale.rangeRound,
and improves the default appearance even without, as long as the axis origin is
at integer coordinates. This is especially noticeable in Safari, where crisp
rendering of single-pixel lines often results in two-pixel lines! Fixes #8.

Use presentation attributes rather than styles to apply the default appearance.
This makes it easier to override the styles using CSS, since any CSS rules will
take precedence of the presentation attributes. Fixes d3/d3#2102.

Extend the default appearance with additional presentation attributes: the
default font is now 10px sans-serif; the domain path and tick lines are now
stroked rather than filled. Fixes #7. Since these are attributes and not styles,
you can easily override the default appearance using CSS. (You can also use
post-selection, as always, to modify the axis.)

This commit also cleans up the axis rendering logic and fixes the transition of
entering ticks: they were previously transitioning in from a tick size of zero,
in addition to fading in. Now they just fade in.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Remove axis.orient.
body:
Instead, construct the axis directly with the given orientation.

This change has several motivations. First, you can’t transition between
orientations, so a mutable orientation makes a false implication. Second, you
should always set an orientation explicitly; relying on the default bottom
orientation made code less clear. Third, symbols for setting orientation are
verbose (axis.orient(axisOrientLeft)) compared to strings (axis.orient("left")),
and especially compared to a dedicated constructor (axisLeft).

Orientation symbols had little value anyway, given that you couldn’t specify a
custom orientation, or save code by eliminating unused orientations.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix #15.
body:
You can clear the brush selection programmatically during a brush gesture, so
the code should not assume that the selection is defined.

Also, you can set the brush selection programmatically during a start event (or
via a timer), so the end event handler must observe the current selection rather
than the selection captured at the gesture’s start.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix brush.move during a brush gesture.
body:
The brush captures the selection at the start of a brush gesture. If the
selection is set programatically by brush.move during a brush gesture, the
captured reference can be different than the brush’s new selection! Now we
always use the element’s current brush selection.

In addition, the brush no longer modifies the selection in-place. If a caller
keeps a reference to the brush selection, it will no longer be affected.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix for more unusual number formats.
body:
According to the CSS Values specification:

> a number is either an integer, or zero or more decimal digits followed by a
> dot (.) followed by one or more decimal digits and optionally an exponent
> composed of "e" or "E" and an integer… the first character of a number may be
> immediately preceded by - or + to indicate the number’s sign.

https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-3/#numbers

Fixes #31.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Implicit parsing of undefined channels.
body:
CSS has no way of expressing an unset channel, and so for example “transparent”
is defined arbitrarily as rgba(0, 0, 0, 0). This module, in contrast, uses NaN
channels to distinguish a channel that is unset. Therefore when parsing CSS
color specifiers, we must record the unset channels (such as the hue being
undefined when the color is black).

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Fix #14 - parse rgba and hsla.
body:
All color spaces now have an “opacity” channel in [0,1]. This is primarily
useful because computed styles often have an alpha component, such as the
default transparent background. Soon, d3-interpolate will be able to interpolate
such RGBA colors automatically!

This commit also standardizes the serialization of colors according to the CSS
Object Model specification, which says to use rgb(R, G, B) when alpha is 1 and
rgba(R, G, B, A) otherwise. This is slightly more verbose than hexadecimal, but
means rgb and rgba colors can be formatted similarly.

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Consolidate interdependent files.
body:
There’s a circular relationship between the generic color parser and the rgb and
hsl constructors: the color parser instantiates an rgb or hsl color with the
parsed channel values, and the rgb and hsl constructors (when called with a
single argument) applies the color parser to first create an RGB color.

There’s also a circular relationship between the Lab and HCL color spaces, since
the latter is a cylindrical transformation of the former.

Some module loaders (notably Babel; see #22) apparently cannot handle circular
dependencies between files. So now the files are merged.

author: Philippe Rivière
subject: voronoi.neighbors
body:
Returns an iterable over the indexes of the cells that share a common edge with the specified cell *i*. Voronoi neighbors are always neighbors on the Delaunay graph, but the converse is false when the common edge has been clipped out by the Voronoi diagram’s viewport.

fixes https://github.com/d3/d3-delaunay/issues/96

author: Philippe Rivière
subject: more collinear tests (https://github.com/d3/d3-delaunay/issues/92)
body:
Since we have a triangulation, there's no need to compute the whole area.
The first non-degenerate triangle we find tells us that the triangulation is not collinear.
This returns immediately in the general case — and it's more accurate in the degenerate cases; and less code!

author: Philippe Rivière
subject: Upgrade to Delaunator@4
body:
Fix Delaunay and Voronoi for degenerate cases

For 0, 1, 2 points, and for collinear points:
- returns the correct topology (neighbors, find)
- returns the correct Voronoi cells (bounding box, half plane…)
- resorts to deterministic jittering only in the case of multiple collinear points

Fixes:
-  https://github.com/d3/d3-delaunay/issues/19
-  https://github.com/d3/d3-delaunay/issues/20
-  https://github.com/d3/d3-delaunay/issues/50

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Workaround Safari optimizer bug.
body:
It appears that Safari optimizes away the arguments when they are passed to
dispatch.apply; the fix is to inline dispatch.apply in dispatch.call. I was
tempted to use slice.call(arguments, 2) here, and that works, but it also
impedes any optimization as described here:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments

I can’t know for sure whether this completely avoids the Safari bug, but it at
least passes the test case here:

http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/3177dec030e92dfd6bf08c89bdef080a

Thanks to @Hypercubed for the report.

 src/dispatch.js | 5 +++--
 1 file changed, 3 insertions(+), 2 deletions(-)

author: Mike Bostock
subject: Use capture on mousemove and mouseup.
body:
This ensures that the drag behavior gets first dibs at these events during an
active gesture. If you stop propagation on the source event during a drag event,
other (non-capturing) event listeners will no longer receive the event.
